utterances: Well, she's still living in New Orleans.
She was able to move back.
Her mother was also ill and unfortunately, due to diabetes, her mother's leg had to be amputated.
Her children though are doing really well.
She's got kids ranging from college age to sixth grade, and she's been able to enroll them in school and so - in that way at least, life is getting back to normal.
What about the infrastructure down there, Farai, and all that goes on in just trying to logistically get around the town.
I understand that things as simple as street signs aren't even up, so it's sometimes hard to even navigate your way there.
It is.
I mean sometimes - you know, a lot of times myself and this time producer Devon Robbins(ph) were down there.
And I'd say, what was that?

Because on one side, the side we were driving on, there'd be no sign but sometimes there'd be a sign facing the other direction, so she'd have to turn around in the seat and try to look over her shoulder and she'd be like, oh yeah, that was our street, we missed it.
We did a lot of U-turns.
And what really struck me the most is that the electricity goes off, the water goes off or there's no water.
People are really living in a very rustic style, and you've got to give people a lot of props for doing that.
Yeah.
Farai, I will also look forward to new stories from you.
Not long after the 9/11 attacks, the U.S.
government began to secretly comb through international banking transactions hoping to find terror suspects.
That program focuses on a database known as SWIFT.
It's a clearing house for virtually every international banking transaction.
It's based in Belgium.
To help us understand just what SWIFT is and what it does, we're joined by Rowan Bosworth Davies.
He's a financial crime consultant at a company called Control Risks Group in London.
And welcome to the program.
Thank you.
Tell us, what is SWIFT?
SWIFT is an international means of transmitting financial information about financial transactions between banks and financial institutions around the world.
It's nothing more than a gateway to passing information from one institution to another.
And what kind of information does it have?
It has information about financial transactions.
So if I wanted to send money from my bank in London to your bank in - I guess you're in Los Angeles, I think, aren't you?

I would just ask my bank to send specific sum of money to your bank and as long as I had the coordinates of your bank, they would send the message from my bank, which would go to my correspondent bank in New York and my correspondent bank in New York would connect to your correspondent bank in New York.
And they in turn would then pass that message on to your bank wherever you happened to be.
And does it give any information, any identifying information as to who is sending this?
And where the person is?
Yes, the amount of information that is in the message depends entirely on the person making the remittance.
The SWIFT requirements are quite detailed.

They like to have as much information as possible about the person making the remittance, and - well, in the sense of obviously name the account from which it's coming, the account to which it's going, and the amount of money that's being transferred and the currency that it's being transferred in.

Now, what does happen sometimes is that you don't always have to fill up every single field in the form because as long as you have the basic information in the instructions form then the transaction will still go through.
And so could SWIFT be a pretty effective tool in trying to uncover terrorist financing?
Well, it's a very difficult question.
Insofar as any investigation looking for terrorist financing is concerned, it's going to be an effective use of investigator's time.

One of the things I think we have to recognize is that, you know, terrorists, generally speaking, are very efficient organizations and they generally tend not to use names and identifiable features which would necessarily automatically track back to a government agency.

So what you - you would still need to be able to have knowledge of the names or the aliases under which these people were operating in order to be able to identify any transactions that are taking place.
And as the Los Angeles Times noted today, al-Qaida is using a less formal means of transferring money, not even going through the SWIFT program.
There are many forms of transmitting money which don't have to use the SWIFT system.
SWIFT is a legitimate and genuine source of investigation for any investigator and certainly would be something which I would be shocked and horrified if I discovered that the U.S.
government had not used that avenue of investigation.
But I don't believe it will necessarily give them all the answers they're looking for.
Thank you very much.
Actors Nathan Lane and Matthew Broderick, the stars of ""The Producers,"" will join us in a few minutes.
The movie version of the musical opens tomorrow in some cities and around the country later this month.
They'll be our main guests this hour.
If you have questions for them, you can call now.
The e-mail address is totn@npr.org.
But we begin in Iraq with an update on today's parliamentary elections.
Polls around the country closed some five hours ago.
Turnout was reported to be strong, even in Sunni-dominated areas, where voting in last January's first nationwide parliamentary election was low.
There was a shortage of ballots in some precincts and long lines outside of some polling stations, and in those areas polling was extended by an hour.
And violence was reported to be relatively low.
We begin in Baghdad, where Time magazine's Baghdad bureau chief Michael Ware joins us.
Michael, good to talk with you.
It's a great pleasure.
I know you were out walking in several neighborhoods in Baghdad earlier today.
What did you see?
Well, I saw a marked contrast across a large part of the city.
I firstly went to one largely Shia area, which is relatively safe, and there it was an election day much of the nature that we would experience ourselves back home.
A little further to the west was another Shia area but much more of a militant zone, where the militias of the rebel cleric Moqtada al-Sadr posed demonstration.
Yet they too voted.
Most interestingly, though, was an area right to the west of the city, nestled close to the largest American military base in the country at Baghdad Airport.
The area is known as el-Morya.
It is to this day an insurgent hot spot.
It is--the community strongly supports the guerrilla fighters.
It is a battlefield today between US forces and the insurgents.
It's a staging post and an operational center for the insurgents.
And today I saw their community, indeed the families of these insurgents, voting en masse.
This fits with what the nationalist insurgents called for prior to this election.
They said, `We're participating; we want our people to participate.
And I got to witness it today.
And, indeed, most of the insurgent groups had said, `We need to let the voting go ahead.
Al-Qaeda in Iraq did not agree, yet violence was pretty low today.
Absolutely.
This is what we see as an enormous dynamic playing out with the insurgency.
There's been a shift in the tectonic plates over the last few months.

Where Zarqawi and his al-Qaeda forces very much have had the upper hand in the command and control of the insurgency thanks to money and their fierce zealotry, we've watched as we've seen the balance shift back in the favor of the Iraqi nationalists--that's the Baath Party--and more moderate Iraqi Islamists.
They now can say, `We want to engage in this political process.
It's been part of their intention since day one to track bullets and ballots strategy, very classic guerrilla style.
They've told Zarqawi, `We're participating.
You must stand back.
So just like we saw in the October referendum there when they participated as nationalists, they forced Zarqawi to stand off and there was no suicide bombings on that day, nor today.
It's going to take at least a couple of weeks, we're told today, before these ballots can be tallied.
There were, though, some questions about missing trucks full of ballots and other concerns over the validity of this election.

Well, there's been enormous concerns about the integrity of these voting processes, both from the original January 30 election, again on the referendum day in October, and I'm sure there's much more yet to emerge from today in terms of allegations.
I mean, during the January election, I myself saw a number of things that would be considered heinous back in the West, just in terms of the handling of ballots and so forth.
However, to what degree it is, as to whether it affects the actual nature of the mandate that might be delivered, I'd be surprised to say that it does.
Certainly we're now entering the real period.
Today was just election day.
The real carve-up of power is only now about to begin.
This was the foreplay, the real name game is only now before us, and this will be, as US military intelligence described it to me, bare-knuckled politics.
Michael Ware, thanks very much for being with us today.
It's my great pleasure.
Thank you, Neal.
Michael Ware, Baghdad bureau chief for Time magazine, speaking with us from Baghdad in--the Iraqi capital.
Let's go now to the largely Sunni city of Fallujah, about 40 miles west of Baghdad, where The Washington Post's Jonathan Finer joins us.
And, Jonathan, good of you to join us tonight.
Oh, thanks for having me on.
Turnout in Fallujah was very low back in January when many Sunnis boycotted the elections.
How did things go today?
Well, it was a very high turnout.

They think in the great Fallujah area something like 200,000-plus residents came out to vote, which would be around 90 percent or more turnout, by far the highest in Anbar province, which is considered the heartland, not only of the Sunni-Arab population in Iraq but of the insurgency.
What was security like?
Security was fairly tight, although the interesting thing about it here in Fallujah is that it was provided almost entirely, at the polling stations at least, by the Iraqi police.
The US Marines who patrol this city, a battalion of them, stayed--did not come within a couple hundred yards of any of the polling stations.
They did some light patrolling and set up a sort of a cordon or parameter around the city.
But aside from that, they left the security to the Iraqi police, and there were very few incidents.
And were you able to figure out what people were talking about, what--as they were on their way to the polls?
And as for educational consultant Jeff Levy, he says families need to start thinking about financial aid much earlier than they do now.
- water, but you can't make him drink.
Yeah.
There's sort of a double agenda that people have here: One, they don't like the government that's in Baghdad.
It's a Shiite Muslim religious-led government--and wanted to come out and vote to try to prevent a government like that from being elected again.
And the other thing they want, very clearly, just about everyone we talked to, was for US troops to withdraw from their cities and eventually to withdraw from Iraq entirely.
And the only difference was--among voters was the timetable for that.
Some wanted it to happen immediately; others said, you know, not right away because the security situation doesn't warrant a complete withdrawal, but we do want it eventually.
But did you get a sense the Sunni representation in the national parliament--that this was an important matter?
Absolutely.
You know, the thing that I think some leaders in the Sunni community and others worry about is whether or not unrealistic expectations are being created.
The Sunnis are still a small minority of Iraq's population; some estimates place them under 20 percent of the population as a whole.
So even if they do elect representatives in proportion of their share of the population, it's not entirely clear that they'll be able to enact much of an agenda once they get through a legislature.

And the concern, I guess, is that once these people who have boycotted politics and are now participating--if they're disillusioned by the fact that their representatives aren't able to bring about the changes that they want to see, the question then becomes whether or not they will stay and sort of embrace in the political process or turn to other means of resistance.
And, Jonathan Finer, give us an update, if you would.
Obviously Fallujah was a city devastated, at least parts of it, during various military operations.
Has reconstruction there gotten under way?
Has the government been able to provide some evidence of--deliver on promises?
